posts.name: Krste Simeonov
posts.headline: Enthusiastic about startups. Perpetual learner.
posts.text:
Now I better understand why my 12-year-old sister answered "NO" when I asked her: "Are you Happy?"

Happiness = Health + Wealth + Quality Relationships

---

Health = Exercise + Diet + Sleep + (Sunlight and avoiding drugs and alcohol)

Exercise = High Intensity Resistance Training + Sports/Cardio + Rest

Diet = Natural food + Intermittent fasting + Plants

Sleep = No alarms + 8-9 hours + Circadian Rhythms + (Fully dark room + 18¬∞C + no food and exercise at least 3 hours before sleep)

---

Wealth = Income + Wealth * (Return On Investment)

Income = Accountability + Leverage + Specific Knowledge

Accountability = Personal Branding + Personal Platform + Taking Risk

Leverage = Capital + People + Intellectual Property

Specific Knowledge = Knowing how to do something that society cannot yet easily train other people to do

Return on Investment = Buy and Hold + Valuation + Margin of Safety

---

Quality Relationships = (Trust + Value + Dialog) * Complexity of the human nature¬†

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
üìç POSITIONING: Campaign tool vs. Operations tool

In the last two months, we brought our churn rate below 5%.
Also, this month our MRR has grown 36% more than the previous month, and we're growing 20-30% MoM consistently for 6 months.

So, what's the secret here?
üëâ HeyReach shifted the positioning from just "a campaign tool" to a tool that our users integrated into their operations.

We are selling mostly to lead-gen agencies (some even call us "The Smartlead for LinkedIn). This ICP is the most creative one, experiments a lot, has the highest churn (compared to sales teams, recruiters, or individuals), and has the most complex outbound stack.

Most of the lead-gen agencies use 5+ different outbound tools (eg: Clay, Instantly.ai, Smartlead, Retention.com, Zapier, HighLevel, Apollo.io & some other wild animals that ColdIQ has on their site). Their outbound stack is integrated and works in perfect harmony. 

üîπ We understood that if we wanted to become a part of their outbound stack (become "sticky", fix our retention, and skyrocket the growth), we needed to integrate deeply into their operations and provide the smoothest experience of doing it. We launched the most flexible LinkedIn API on the market, and dozens of webhook options to export HeyReach data anywhere.

Instead of being just a campaign tool from where you can run LinkedIn outreach sequences, we decided to become "the missing LinkedIn puzzle" of the agencies' outbound stack, and complete the end-to-end streamlining of their outbound processes.

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
üßô LinkedIn Sales Navigator holds immersive power, like The Elder Wand (from Harry Potter). 

Pairing it with HeyReach is like owning the other two Deathly Hallows!

Targeting active LinkedIn users using Sales Navigator is an extremely useful technique! Thanks for sharing this, Reyhan Khan!I Improved my LinkedIn Outreach Results by 300% üìà 


I recently built a campaign to interact with Sales Experts and build more use cases for AI tools and saw a 38.6% reply rate which is 4x more than my usual campaigns. So what's the hack?

Sales Navigator is one of the main sources of prospect lists for me. HeyReach allows me to pull search results directly into an engagement campaign.

Recently, I tested by checking the "Posted on LinkedIn" option in Sales Nav when building my lists and it has done wonders. Simply put, you're only reaching out to people who are active on LinkedIn hence the chances of engagement are higher. 

Attaching campaign results as Proof.


#coldoutbound #leadgeneration #linkedinnetworking

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
üéâ $50K+ MRR in 10 months üéâ

HeyReach just crossed $50K MRR, 10 months after earning its first buck.
This is a huge accomplishment for us, since we were 3 months away from bankruptcy back in June, and couldn't grow past $8K MRR until October.

üéì Key lessons I learned so far:

‚Ä¢ It takes time. Trust your team, trust your gut, and just move.
- Growth takes time. The stories about super-fast growth are exceptions, and you shouldn't fall into the imposter syndrome. It took us 6 months, and 597 meetings to grow above $10K MRR. It's a marathon, not a sprint.

‚Ä¢ Niche down to grow
- Check my last posts - talked a lot about this.

‚Ä¢ Focus on profitability, control your growth
- Forget about GaaC (growth at all costs). It's sexy and looks great, but it's super easy to burn everything you have during these times.

‚Ä¢ We can do anything, we cannot do everything (at once)
- Pick your battles. Most likely, your business feels like a "leaky bucket", and there are a gazillion problems you need to solve, features to add, bugs to fix, and directions to go in. Prioritize everything, take a snapshot of your tasks for that month/quarter, and just execute. Repeat this every month/quarter.

‚Ä¢ Customer-centric development is the way to go
- Your short-term roadmap should be built by your customers & closed-lost deals. It's not rocket science - once you have your first 10-50 customers, just listen to them and build the product for their needs.

Hats off to the whole HeyReach team - cheers to you! üçª

ü¶Ñ Next milestone: 1M ARR.

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
With email outreach, you can only dream about the 30-60% reply rate you can get via LinkedIn as a channel (hats off to the exceptions).

On the other hand, with LinkedIn outreach, you can only dream about scaling your outreach to the extent you can reach with email as a channel (unless you are using HeyReach üòú).

üß† The biggest factor is: 
Replying to name@company.com vs. replying to a person.

And this is my observation:
- When you get a cold email from some company that you are not familiar with it's much easier to ignore it (we are used to ignoring cold emails), compared to getting a message from someone whom you already accepted in your network. The psychological background is that on LinkedIn you're replying to a person who has a profile picture, works somewhere, posts stuff on their profile, has interests, and most importantly - you decided to add/accept them in your network. On email you are just talking with an email address that maybe has a signature.

üí´ In the end, the core of sales is "personal relationships" - buying and selling to people, and the next best thing to in-person relationship building is LinkedIn.

PS: IMO, if you can manage to be "known" to the prospect you're reaching out to (i.e. they've seen your content, they know about your company, etc.) your overall outreach can perform much much better, regardless of the outreach channel. Content-led sales FTW! ü§ò

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
üìä LinkedIn outreach to your free trial users: 8% to %16 conversion rate increase

What if you can connect with everyone who has shown interest in your product, get them to your network, and start a conversation with them? A precious thing üíé for a founder - right?

One of our newest & gonna-become-a-go-to-campaign at HeyReach is auto-connecting with our free trial users, and reaching out to them. This campaign has brought amazing results so far and has doubled out fully-activated to converted rate.

üîó Acceptance rate: 64.1%
üí¨ Reply rate: 25.3%

You can do the same thing for your SaaS, and I'll show you how we do it.

üî∞ Step-by-step:
1. Upload your list of free trials in HeyReach
- Nikola Siljanoski adds the new free trial users in HeyReach every morning, into a list we call "Free Trial Signups". If you don't have their LinkedIn profiles, feel free to reach out to Rahul Lakhaney with Enrich.so to understand how to convert their email addresses to a LinkedIn profile.

2. Automated HeyReach sequence
- We start by sending an automated blank connection request. So, the free trial user gets a connection request from the founder of the tool they'd just started a free trial. Pretty nice, huh?
Then, after 4 days (enough time to play around with the tool), we send a simple automated message that says:
‚û°Ô∏è "Hey hey {firstName}, tnx for accepting me! How's your HeyReach experience so far?".

And that's it. A simple conversation-starter that helps me get in touch with our customers.

3. Talk to your free trial users
- Most of the users you reach out to reply back, and your only job here is to listen to their feedback and help them if they are stuck somewhere in their activation journey.

üìà This approach has doubled our activated to converted rate, and has helped me talk to our potential users.

Check the comments for a link to the blog post, where I showcase the whole sequence! üçª

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
Niche down to expand - how to do it successfully?! üé£

Having a huge TAM is crucial for building a huge business, but finding a really specific niche is the most important first step of your journey. 
We started growing 34% MoM on avg. after we niched down to a super-specific audience. 

I do believe that niching-down will be really important in 2024, as it‚Äôs really tied to the concept of controlled profitable growth.

‚ú® Niche = very specific audience that‚Äôs part of your TAM, where you bring 10x value, it‚Äôs easy to sell to, the sales cycle is shorter, and they stick with you even when you are buggy. Think of it as a mini-PMF, or a single ICP (ideal customer persona) where you can kill it.

üìê Our formula for niching down to the right audience:
1. Just ship it, and reach out to your ‚Äòfirst hypothetical ICP‚Äô 
- Just launch your first version of your product and start reaching out to your ICP. Keep in mind that your first hypothesis of the ICP may be completely missed, but don‚Äôt feel bad about it. Just iterate until you find it (you have time until you burn out the money).

2. Talk to the closed-won and closed-lost customers. All. The. Time. 
- This is a continuous process that should help you determine what‚Äôs the right initial ICP (your niche). Keep attention to the deals you‚Äôve lost, the deals you‚Äôve won, the users that churned, and the users that are still with you. Ask them ‚Äòwhy‚Äô, and ALWAYS try to truly understand them (their job position, their role, how they are thinking, how they found you, etc.). Be super specific in the details.

3. Your closed-lost deals should build your short-term roadmap 
- This is applicable only after you‚Äôve found your niche. Start tracking the reasons for losing deals (features, pricing, bugs, etc.), as those things will be your short-term product roadmap. Do this until you become the go-to solution in your niche.

4. Become the go-to solution for your niche, and then expand 
- Stay focused on your niche until you dominate it. Build the features they need, improve their experience, and get that sweet market share. However, don‚Äôt feel too comfy, as you shouldn‚Äôt stop here. As Jason M. Lemkin says, the most important job of the CEO is to continuously expand the TAM, year by year. üí•

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
'Growth at all costs' mindset may kill your startup üíÄ

Back in the days (2020-2023), the typical advice you'd hear as a VC-backed startup was "spend more". The main approach was to be maniacally focused on growth and grabbing a bigger market share. The founders were acting like hungry hyenas pouring money into everything that brings growth, overhiring, overspending, and doubling down on untested channels that might bring growth. 

Growth, growth, growth! (in Steve Ballmer's "developers, developers, developers" voice) üå±

In the last couple of months, I've seen a lot of startups going down because of this mentality. 

However, the 'growth' is not the problem. The uncontrolled growth and constant stepping on the gas pedal without a working engine is. 

It's really easy to get into this GAAC (Growth at all costs) mindset before even remotely figuring out, be blinded by the Silicon Valley stories about raising hundreds of millions in Series A, and hope that VC money will always be here to save your company when the things go south. 
If you don't figure it out fast, if you don't have control over the direction you are going, and if you are not obsessed with building a real business the chances of failing are pretty high nowadays.

In June 2023, we were 3 months away from bankruptcy, burning $35-40K per month. It was a wake-up call for us. 

üîπ Lesson learned: Keep it lean until you are pretty positive that you know what you are doing, and you have a pretty good feeling and data informing you that you are ready to scale, burn, and double down on growth.

2024 is the year of predictable and controlled growth with a focus on profitability. Even for VC-backed startups (that are in the process of raising their next round). üìà

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
Do you know that everyone on the HeyReach team does outreach? 
Yep, even the devs... üèπ
* You might even get a message from our CTO, Stefan Kotevski.

However, none of them *really* send messages or manage their inboxes. 
They just have their LinkedIn profiles connected to one automated outreach campaign, and Nikola Siljanoski handles the replies and book demos on their behalf.

Yep, one BDR managing 13 LinkedIn sending accounts - from one simple dashboard.

This way, we can scale our outreach 10x, by using our whole team's accounts. That's 10+ LinkedIn accounts (each one of them sending 20 invites per day), connected on one outreach campaign, automatically rotating their inboxes. 

This approach allows us to reach 200 prospects per day on LinkedIn, totally automatically - with the effort of a single BDR. ü§Ø

üîπ What about the privacy? Do you read their inboxes?
- Nope. HeyReach has a built-in feature that allows you to select your privacy mode for each LinkedIn account (i.e. only share the conversations started with HeyReach).

üé• 3-minute video tutorial in comments!

posts.name: Nikola Velkovski
posts.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
posts.text:
Selling to SMBs is underrated. üëé

Most companies aim at bigger customers, going with the fact that the deal size is higher ($$$$$), the retention is much better, you deal with fewer customers, etc.

While all of this is true, there are some huge drawbacks. The sales cycles are much longer, multiple decision-makers, the outbound approach is different (ABM, requires involvement of the executives, multiple stakeholders, etc.), there's a legal part involved, and there's *almost* always a special requirement.

‚≠êÔ∏è PROs of selling to SMBs:
‚Ä¢ You most likely don't deal with procurement, extensive negotiations, or legal stuff (it can be exhausting, trust me!) 
‚Ä¢ Short sales cycles, especially if you have a "product-customer fit" (different from product-market fit, Bogdan Pasca kudos for the term)
‚Ä¢ If you are a startup, you most likely are closer to their mindset and modus operandi (compared to the mid-market/enterprise customers), and you do understand your customers better
‚Ä¢ Founder-led sales work like a charm, the costs of the tools are SMB-friendly, there's a much larger pool of prospects
‚Ä¢ PLG, word-of-mouth, simple affiliate & sales processes

PS: The picture below is a small leadgen agency (up to 50 LinkedIn seats), that Ilija Stojkovski closed in a 19 min demo! 

No procurement, no negotiations. The simple ol' "Free Trial & Convert" üòé

One thing that fascinates me so much about people blaming MKBHD for "killing this (useless) company" is the fact that a guy with a camera and 0 in funding matters more than $200M+ funded company.

Let that sink in. Never before in history has this been possible. What an incredible world we live in.

Go creators!

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
I am so lucky that Influencers.club is growing as a company without me convincing everyone to post or care about Linkedin.

Can't stand shameless self-promotion, and I am quite sick of all the "look at me me me" posts. 

The point of content is creating value (or fun), not to look at all the product features you are adding. 

If you can combine value for your audience and still benefit your company, amazing! You rock. But if not, please think twice about whether this is the channel for you. 

It's not the end of the world if you are not good at Linkedin. There are countless other channels out there.

I like most of you, and I am here only because I think someone can benefit from our journey, research, or data. 

Here is a picture of our office cat sitting next to me atm, for fun.

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
At the end of every week, I keep realizing more and more that life happens while we build.

There is no end goal. Maybe we'll make it, maybe we won't. 

ARR, MRR, CTR, whatverR, are just metrics that keep us doing what we are doing but you have to feel good at work and around the people you work with. 

There is no exit strategy that can make as long-lasting an impact as the work you are doing and who you are doing it with.

Here is part of my Friday night crew <3

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
Time for a #datastory: In the last newsletter, Kaya Yurieff published how "Linktree Jumps Into Social Commerce" and here are three reasons why that makes a TON of sense.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Linktree's Market Cap

In the first picture, you have Linktree's market cap compared to other link-in-bio tools from 2021 until now. 

Notice how the funding of many competitors didn't phase Linktree at all. There are a few companies that grew like Beacons, Milkshake etc, but not at the cost of Linktree users.  * We analyzed 71 link in bio tools but are displaying only the top 10. 

What this means is that Linktree is still the #1 tool and their word-of-mouth growth is as strong as ever.  

2Ô∏è‚É£ Instagram's poor adoption of the multiple links in bio feature

Instagram added the option for creators to add multiple links in their bios. TechCrunch published an article stating how Meta takes on Linktree, Beacons etc. 

Well, that didn't turn out that well. 

The number of creators who use that feature is ~.02% from the sample of creators we analyzed vs Linktree links at ~12.5%. So you don't have to do the math, that's 62,400%¬†more in favor of Linktree.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Social Commerce Happening Inside Linktree Already

This is probably the main one, there are 13.7% of our sample creators linking to either LTK, ShopMy, or Amazon inside their Linktree link vs only 0.6% who have those 3 as their main link in bio. 

That's a solid chunk and as the data shows far more are using social commerce links inside Linktree than just as their main links. So it makes sense that as a company they would definitely try to use this to their advantage.

How this all plays out I am not sure, but what I am quite sure is that Linktree is not going anywhere, and judging by the data this should be a very good business move for them.

Again, this is not sponsored by anyone nor do I have something to gain from it. It's just interesting to see how these business moves are supported by data.

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
Staying bootstrapped when times were wild was one of the best moves we made as co-founders.

We were a profitable company in the very early days and growing at a great pace, BUT we were

-> struggling to hire engineers
-> other more senior people didn‚Äôt even want to hear about joining a ‚ÄúMacedonian bootstrapped startup‚Äù
-> any serious company in our industry thought that we were an Eastern European joke

So I have to admit, raising at that time would have been a relief from the constant battle to solve those issues.

But they didn‚Äôt necessarily have to be solved with capital. They could be solved by us working our asses off until we proved that we are worth it.

And we did.

Then 2021 came.

Money started raining from everywhere. We spoke to companies that had much less than 0 in revenue and yet raised tens of millions of dollars.

So we got offers too.

‚ÄúYou are missing out if you are not raising a round now.‚Äù
‚ÄúMoney is free; you should take it!‚Äù
‚ÄúThe creator economy will be worth trillions of billions of millions of dollars; get that money now.‚Äù

Mostly thanks to Hugo Amsellem and Boris Sokolov (I almost cracked at that point), we put our heads down and focused on the fundamentals again, working tirelessly but keeping the company independent.

We didn‚Äôt sprint; we ran a marathon. 20% growth, then another 20%, and then another 20%.

Then 2023 happened. A big, big percentage of the companies that raised those millions are going under or selling for peanuts.

And influencers.club? Well, we continued with our 20% growth marathon.

Not distracted by shiny things, not letting the market blind us, and focusing only on fundamentals.

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
Curious about what kind of YouTubers you'll meet at VidCon?

I took 30,000 YT creators who have posted about Vidcon to try to come up with the "average YouTube creator" attending the conference. 

Here are the stats:

  ‚ñ∂ Average YouTube Subscriber Count: Around 146,666 subscribers. (impressive!)
  ‚ñ∂ Average YouTube Video Count: Approximately 128 videos uploaded to their channel
  ‚ñ∂ Average YouTube Views: An average of about 117,023 views per video
  ‚ñ∂ Average YouTube Engagement Percent: Approximately 4.80% engagement rate
  ‚ñ∂ They are mostly English-speaking although we detected 23 different languages in the dataset

My thoughts: These are impressive numbers for all companies that want to meet quality, dedicated creators in person. 

Fun fact: There were more than 1000 creators above 1M followers in the dataset and the creator with the highest average view count (15M) was from India.

This post is in no way sponsored by Vidcon btw, it was just fun to do. Buy your tickets now!

posts.name: Nikola Sokolov
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow. Co-Founder @influencers.club
posts.text:
One year into the #AI revolution and #creators are using AI almost 300% more than last year!

One year ago, we worked with one of the biggest beauty brands in the world üëÄ  to survey 500 beauty creators (10k+, US, beauty niche) with a few questions one of them being:

 "Are you using any AI tools for content creation?"

The results were the following:

‚ñ∂ 49.7% No, but I'm open to trying 
‚ñ∂ 11% Yes, I use them regularly 
‚ñ∂ 16.2% Sometimes when I'm feeling stuck or need some help 
‚ñ∂ 23.1% No, I'm not planning on using them

Now a year later, we asked the same question again, and the results are incredible.

‚ñ∂ 29.6% said they use AI regularly (Almost x3!!!)
‚ñ∂ 37.1% said no but I am open to trying them out 
‚ñ∂ 22.2% Sometimes when I'm feeling stuck or need some help 
‚ñ∂ 11.1% No, I'm not planning on using them ( half of what the number was last year)

Here is me in Lisbon amazed at the results. If you are here btw, let's meet up!

name: Kiril Dameski
headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
Uscreen is a bootstrapped, 20M+ ARR brand. Let‚Äôs see how they are helping video creators.

Uscreen is an all-in-one video membership platform. 

25k+ professional #creators (trainers, educators, coaches, entertainers) use the platform to:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Set up memberships - sell or rent content on a pay-per-view basis
2Ô∏è‚É£ Launch their own app - making content accessible on mobile, TV, web ü§Ø
3Ô∏è‚É£¬†Build a self-sustaining community
4Ô∏è‚É£¬†Have a Netflix-style video catalog, do live streaming, and more

Founded in 2014 by PJ Taei who is a college dropout ‚úÖ and a x2 founder: 

‚ÄúWe happened to be at the right place and at the right time with the pandemic. 

By the time the pandemic hit, we had a full-featured product that sold itself. 

Our SEO engine was primed with useful content for creators looking to move their businesses towards video memberships.‚Äù

‚Üí Employees: 130+
‚Üí End users: 9.7M¬†
‚Üí Basic pricing: $199/mo
‚Üí Notable customers: Yoga with Adrienne, Amy Landino, Brandon Washington, OnlyPaige.
‚Üí Leadership:
 PJ Taei - CEO & Founder
 Srey Sankar - CMO
 Matt Estes - COO
 Nick Savrov - CTO

Thanks Rob Balasabas, Salma Madwar, and Laura James for providing me with all the info I needed. ü§ü 

--------------------------------------------------------

I‚Äôm trying to better understand top creator companies.

What's their product, target audience, and overall, how are they influencing the #creatoreconomy.

Would love to hear your suggestions on who should be next? üëá

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
63 Tiktokers shared with us how much money they made in 2023. 

Despite having ‚âà100k fans, over half of them made less than $1k.¬†üò¢ 

But I have to give a bit of context about the creators we reached out to. 

‚Ü≥ Location: UK, US 
‚Ü≥ TikTok fans: 90k - 110k
‚Ü≥ Have less than 20k fans on Instagram or Youtube

So, we targeted TikTokers who weren't popular on other platforms.

It's obvious that creators can't rely only on Tiktok and that they need a cross-platform presence. 

On the other hand, we can see that there are still a ton of creators who need assistance with their businesses (tools, strategies, operational help, etc). 

And that need will only increase. 
------

Have a topic in mind for our next creator survey? üëá

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
Here's why the biggest B2C brands target influencers who build communities. 

Based on data from 100k creators we can finally see the impact communities have on engagement rates. 

Are you ready? 

Here's the added engagement a creator can expect IF they have a community: 

YouTube ‚ûú 30% increase in engagement rate.
Instagram ‚ûú 38% increase in engagement rate.
TikTok ‚ûú 20% increase in engagement rate.

Creators! Don't think twice about starting a community! We found that the most common platforms are Discord, Patreon, Kajabi, and Thinkific. 

And brands, we have 100k+ of these community building creators. Reach out if you need access to our database. üòâ 

There are A LOT more data-driven insights in the report. Check it out below.

ps. Thanks to all contributors to this report from Patreon, Kajabi, Nas Company, and Clubhouse.

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
In a few weeks we‚Äôll publish data on how much money Tiktokers with ‚âà100k fans made in 2023. 

But check out the first reply we got from a creator.¬†üëá 

I created the survey with one question about their income and offered predefined answers. 

The lowest option you can select is "Under $10,000‚Äù. 

As it turns out, the majority of the 20 respondents we have so far earned under 10k. 

I guess we need to modify the answers, offer even lower options, and start the survey again.

It will be interesting to see the actual numbers at the end.

p.s. all of these creators are from the US & UK. 

p.p.s. once we have the chart for Tiktok we also plan on doing the same for Instagram and Youtube creators.

Stay tuned!

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
Have you noticed the trend of well-known creators quitting Youtube?

Here‚Äôs why that‚Äôs happening:

Most creators start by making videos around a topic they love.

After a while, they get good at it and start gaining new subs.

Life‚Äôs good.

To keep up, they start playing by YouTube's rules and that's when the treadmill starts. üèÉüèÉüèº‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉüèª‚ôÇÔ∏èüèÉüèª‚ôÄÔ∏è 

Publishing videos according to a schedule -> hiring a video editor -> negotiating brand deals -> managing finances -> coming up with new ideas -> hiring assistants -> searching for new brand deals -> CONSTANTLY PUBLISHING NEW VIDEOS!

Initially, it was about creating fun videos. Now, most of their time is spent managing people.

They start to lose their passion, which often ends up with burnout. 

That‚Äôs why so many quit. 

But that‚Äôs not surprising, right? It‚Äôs always been this way.

Over 90% of startups fail because growing a business is hard and not for everyone.

To end on a positive note, I think this is another sign that the #creatoreconomy is still developing.

The demand for tools and services to assist these new creator-led businesses will only increase.

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:

More info about the company:

‚Üí Team size: 390 (on Linkedin)¬†
‚Üí Leadership: Ahad Khan (CEO), Sean (Solme) Kim (President and Chief Product Officer), Kenny Rueter (Executive Chairman & Co-founder)¬†
‚Üí Basic pricing: $149/mo

--------------------------------------------------------

I‚Äôm trying to better understand top creator companies.

What's their product, who are they serving, and overall, how are they influencing the creator economy. 

Let me know who should be next. üôè 

I‚Äôm thinking Jellysmack, Fanfix, or Fourthwall.

posts.name: Kiril Dameski
posts.headline: Helping A-star creator economy companies grow | Head of marketing @ Influencers Club
posts.text:
What are creators linking in their link-in-bio pages?

This is a new analysis based on 745k creators with a link-in-bio page (Linktree, Koji, Beacons, etc.) that are in our database.

It‚Äôs interesting to see where creators are redirecting their followers.

Happy (and surprised) to see LinkedIn so high on the list.

A lot of #musicians and #podcasters are linking out to Spotify, Soundcloud, Apple Music & Bandcamp.

Threads have a long way to go to come even near X.

And if you‚Äôre wondering where Patreon is, they almost didn't make the cut (literally 2 places below Bandcamp).

What other platform is missing here? ü§ö 

*whatsapp is a flaw in the data, so please disregard that.

#creatoreconomy #creators

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
Build your brand. Not theirs.

One of my favorite Fourthwall features is that every creator gets their own mobile app. 

These are designed as "progressive web apps" (PWAs), which means that creators can also avoid the Apple / Google 30% tax. 

This is part of our mission of giving creators full ownership. You own your brand, your app, your data, your domain, and your website (down to the code). 

We give you the tools to make it easier to connect with your superfans.Free mobile apps. Fully branded to you. Only on Fourthwall¬†üì± 

We are thrilled to¬†announce¬†a unique feature only available on Fourthwall - the launch of¬†fully branded mobile apps for all creators!

Starting today, all creators who use Fourthwall to power their memberships will automatically gain access to their own mobile apps, offering an unparalleled level of convenience and member engagement. Creators who had early access to their own app saw an¬†increase of up to 29% in engagement!

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
More creators have signed up on Fourthwall in the past 10 weeks than in our first 4 years combined. But my favorite part:

Helping creators to launch their brands, build their business, give back to their community, and make life-changing money. All in a weekend.

Fourthwall is now the best place for individuals with audiences to sell products online ‚Äî whether that's physical goods (from merch to hot sauce and more), digital products, or subscription memberships. 

We're still at the very beginning of what Fourthwall will become, but we're focused on making the product 1% better every single day. We move fast to make these little details add up even faster. 

Props to Leah Cede√±o for highlighting this in the video below.

If you're interested in launching your shop or scaling your brand, drop a note below. Excited to help more and more creative artists to succeed. Over 50,000 creators power their sites with Fourthwall üí™ Sign up today to get your own custom homepage, shop, and memberships for free! ‚ú®

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
Growth people - 

What tools do you use to run in product (post auth) experiments? 

Specifically, we have a lot of different recommendations in the Fourthwall dashboard to help you launch your shop. We're looking to experiment with copy, ordering, imagery, etc to increase activations rates.

We're ideally looking for a tool (or tools) that:

1. Allows for custom cohorts
2. Is no code (at least post setup) for anyone to run
3. Run experiments to stat sig
4. Requires little/no maintenance

Do you use anything for your team? If so, do you like it?

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
The very first feature we ever built on Fourthwall? Letting fans leave a message on checkout.

Not only does this increase conversion rates for creators (counter-intuitive for traditional ecomm), but it also builds community engagement. 

Starting today, you can now share these messages straight to socials. And of course, you can send a personalized thank you video to your fans for all orders.

Would love your feedback. Let me know what you think about this release belowDid you know you can now share your favorite supporter messages directly to your socials? üëÄ üíñ Check it out now in the Fourthwall app üåü

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
How often do you think creator sites get hit with DDoS attacks? 

Answer:

At least on Fourthwall, we see these occur 1-2 times per day. 

I should also note that these aren't even targeted against "offensive" creators. They happen to creators that mostly make kids content. 

I'm sharing this chart from a few hours ago where we saw:
 - A spike of ~200k requests from a DDoS attack
 - 0 failures on our end

We've invested a lot in our core infrastructure to handle these without any downtime over the years, especially given the frequency with which these happen. 

I mostly think this is due to the asymmetric nature of an attack. You can ruin someone's big launch day by paying ~$100 for a DDoS (and potentially crashing their site if they don't use a platform like Fourthwall that protects you from these). The trolling nature of the internet makes this surprisingly common.

When starting Fourthwall, I would have never guessed that we'd have needed to make such an investment in protecting against DDoS. But here we are. And I'm grateful that we can handle these without missing a beat (0 failed requests for today's attack). 

What do you think? Do you see a similar frequency of attacks in your space?

posts.name: Will Baumann
posts.headline: Co-founder & CEO at Fourthwall
posts.text:
At Fourthwall, we've grown SEO-based revenue 500%+ and impressions 1123%+ (and counting!). All without being SEO experts. How? Backstory time:

We‚Äôve long assumed that SEO would be a key lever at Fourthwall. Why?
¬†- Most creators sites on Fourthwall (like MKBHD) have a ‚ÄúPowered by Fourthwall‚Äù backlink in the footer
¬†- Therefore our rapid creator growth should rapidly build domain authority

But we had no idea where to begin. Here's what happened next:

1. Lenny Rachitsky interviewed Ethan Smith on his podcast about SEO. If you haven't listened, it's by far the most information-dense podcast on SEO. I immediately knew we had to work with the Ethan & the Graphite team. (PS - Lenny sells his new book on Fourthwall. You should buy one.)
2. A few weeks later, I flew to one of Yuriy Timen's amazing founder dinners to meet Ethan (who now co-hosts these)
3. At the dinner, I asked Ethan a 100+ SEO questions and pitched him on why they should let Fourthwall be one of the first users of Graphite's new self-serve tooling

Two weeks later, we got started. Five months later, results were booming üìàüìà (huge props to Cosette Libier from our team for owning the execution).

As a founder, I highly recommend Graphite's new self-serve platform. It immediately 100x'ed our abilities and will become the top SEO tool for teams that are serious about search-based growth the moment it's available to the public.

Thankfully, we get to keep our SEO competitive advantage for a bit longer as it's still waitlist only. But if you want early access (or just have questions about SEO in general), drop a comment below.
